result of this statement on page two of the early poll that in March of 1933 fandom didn't exist.
I wrote variants of it to the three main promas. It never surfaced in Amazing, even though it
contained a leader commenting on the 50th anniversary issue and how Amazing, under Grinsbeck, had
actually spawned the very first fan org. Then Boba returned to postcard saying that's fandom,
and here at Analog we don't get into fandom. Galaxy, which does get into fandom, also sank the
letter to that trace. Then I wrote Algro and direct reply to that having reprinted the statement by
Paul and I've been told they printed the letter but I haven't seen that issue. Grinsbeck ran quite
a letter column and printed the addresses in full so from almost the first there was some
correspondence between the readers. Finally Ray Palmer organized it. He seems to have written to
everyone whose address had appeared. The result was the Science Correspondence Club. The magazine
began in 1926. The club may have started as early as 1928 or as late as 1929. I'm sure it was not as
early as 1927. The name was later changed to International Scientific Association. Then one
summer day I answered a ring at our door and a tall dark young man asked if my brother was on
him. Well I had three brothers but I assumed he meant the older one. Turns out that's what he assumed
too. You mean Alan I asked? No he said Clifton. It was Auburn and Brenna. The next one he contacted
was Lester Anderson and Haber. We formed the East Bay Scientific Association and the name
would never change even after we had members in San Francisco. I know it lasted until at least 1935
and maybe later. Auburn says it must have been started in 1928 because he has something about
it in my handwriting dated 1928 and it now. I know it had to be after the current organization became
International Scientific Association because we copied that name. I'm also very sure it had to be
1930 because I recall it was just after I'd come home after shipping on a tanker district in
Columbia and an old in the University of California summer session and that was 1930.
After the international organization responded, Gernsback had one of his cover picture stories
contest. I think it was the first one maybe the only one from Amazing. I toyed with trying to
write a story to Andrew but Roy Palmer wrote one and won. I believe the prize money was a hundred
dollars. He used it to buy the organization a mimeograph and put out a club or a big cosmology.
You could get quite a mimeograph for a hundred dollars in those days.
Anyway from then on the president was also editor. By 1932 Auburn was president and editor
and I was secretary and assistant editor. In passing through two or three hands something had happened
to the mimeograph. What we received from past president Eaton in Atlanta was not a machine.
Eaton swore it was just what he had received from his predecessor. The mimeograph drum was
flattened out to about a quarter circle. A flat deck was laid over it and a handle put in the middle
of the deck. This you held and leaned on while rolling the drum and stencil length of the sheet
of paper. I've seen them since for postcard size but that's the only one I ever saw for eight and a
half by eleven paper. I saw quite too much of it. Auburn saw more. I left in August 1932 to go to
be graduate assistant in anthropology at the University of Nebraska. I stopped to see some
members in Oregon and Washington and hitchhiked to Milwaukee where I made the same mistake with
Ray that Auburn made with me. The first thought I had when he opened the door was my guy,
he didn't tell me his younger brother was hunchbacked too. All the time I was there Ray was
warning me about the people I'd be staying with in Chicago. Walter Dennis was founder and president
of the Chicago Club. Ray had visited and told me Dennis's mother was German and said great store
of good food and would keep insisting I have more at meals and forcing it on me. Actually I didn't
see anything unusual and nobody forced anything on me. The Chicago Club was actually not very
active finish. They had founded an astronomy club based on the then bright new Adler Panitarium
and the astronomy club would sort of squabble the pan blow. Ray had also mentioned our one member in
Lincoln where I was going. It was one of our few girl or young women members and it seemed some
of Ray's letters had been rather glowing. Incidentally just as I always signed my name CHA,
small letter H and small letter A, Ray always used RAP, small A and small P. I think we both
started that before either of us wrote to the other. I asked my lift into Lincoln how to get to
the fans address. Why? That sounds like it's down in Russian town he said making a plane
known to want to go or go anyone down there. It seemed everyone down there spoke German.
As a matter of fact, there were in that part of town many people from Russia being well good
Germans like many of the lovers on the northern California Mendocino coast who were Lucian Finns.
Well I found the place but it wasn't well. It seemed she was recently married and her husband
had seen at least one of Ray's letters. Ray had known it as she had written to ask him not to send
any more. I can't recall whether I shamed off my beard at Milwaukee or after I got to Lincoln.
Dr. Miles J. Brewer also lived at Lincoln. His office was in the building a block and a half
from where I got a room. I never did see. His receptionist evidently didn't approve of science
fiction and let me know I was on World War One. Christmas vacation I went to Boston to visit
the other local fan club. We believed that it was older than the Chicago one but probably not as old
as East Bay. At some time briefly there seems to have been one in New York City but just when I
don't know. Maybe Connie Ruppert might know. He put out science fiction digest and I spent a couple
of days with him. He lived in South Ozone Park then in one of those hyphenated Queens addresses.
While others around Boston I visited as I recall one of the Oregon members named Ockerman
possibly with two Ns who was going to MIT. He was in nuclear chemistry. There were very few of them.
Now I guess they're all absorbed in the nuclear physics. That winter or the next one I believe
Washington University near St. Louis, Aaron Hubbard and John Camel Jr. were taking the very first
class ever given called nuclear physics. During his dianetics period Camel announced that he had
discovered that ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny was a very important pangoramic phrase behind his
mind and he couldn't understand why it should be so strong in the mind of a physical scientist.
Then he remembered that he grew up in the household of a biologist. But he seems never to have made
the connection between the above facts and his lifelong dedication to the proposition
many cultural phenomena are of genetic origin. Incidentally the weather that winter was very
cold and deep snows hit just before I started. I couldn't hitchhike. I went by freight to Elizabeth
New Jersey and by a bus from New York City to Boston and back then freight back to Lincoln.
After that storm Ray wrote the East wind blew off the frozen lake and made it even colder in
Milwaukee. He took pictures of hot water to the second floor window, poured them out in front
of people coming along. The outside of the water would freeze on the way down, shatter against the
rock and a cloud of steam would rise up in front of him. On the other hand how much of that Ray
wrote me is true as questionable. Other people say he wrote them different accounts of his life at that time.
To change the subject completely, Spider Robinson's recent column on books by women
inspired me to write him quite a letter. One of the points I made to him was that I couldn't
understand why it took him so long to accumulate all those books because most of them were old books.
Even at the time, even considering how long it takes to get something published in Amazing.
However, since I wrote him the letter I've been thinking more about women writers of science fiction
and it's true. There have always been women writers of science fiction. There have always been very
good women writers of science fiction. The point is there have not been the cloud of mediocre
women science fiction writers as there has been a cloud of mediocre men science fiction writers.
Regardless of whether they use their own names or their initials or a fake name,
still for a woman to break into science fiction writing she had to be real good.
And then of course there's the recent June 1977 women's issue of analog.
He said, Ben Bovitt said that he could not get women artists. It's very strange.
At the same time this thing was on the stands, there was an issue of galaxy on the stands
with a cover and interior work by Bonnie Delzell. And oddly enough her work for that galaxy
was very very similar to the cover art and inside work that appeared by a man on the women's issue
of analog. Totally unlike other and to my eyes better work by Bonnie Delzell. And by the way
did you see the AP wire photo of the Prudhoe Bay control room for the Alaska pipeline?
I swear those two hard hats sitting there are aliens or maybe one of them's only half alien.
The names are Margus, M-A-R-G-I-S, Frechtl, F-R-E-I-C-H-T-L, and the other one is named
Blav, FunTempt, F-U-N-T-E-M-P-T. Surely those are not birth names. Maybe they were devised by Jack Vance.
